body:
At one point, I had a test bed that exercised it and became aware of the problem. Since we had no code to exercise it, I pushed it off until we had a GUI, which will definitely need it. See issue #166, which is marked status:blocked.

WorkItem doesn't start any threads. Do you mean that the user code starts them?

Tests that start threads of their own have always been a problem for NUnit, so it's no surprise that they cause a problem here. I think this probably should be solved for the simpler cases first.
One possible solution for tests that start their own thread is to go ahead and run the TearDown method for an aborted Test.  Currently, the TearDown method is not run if the test is aborted.
It is possibly related that the ITestListener.TestFinished event is only raised once if  StopRun is called - for the currently running test.  Not for parent tests, or for the fixture or assembly.

The theory is that the detection of a cancelled test should ripple upward
through all the containing tests. It's fragile though.

On Sun, Jan 10, 2016 at 9:51 PM, Neil Colvin notifications@github.com
wrote:

> It is possibly related that the ITestListener.TestFinished event is only
> raised once if StopRun is called - for the currently running test. Not for
> parent tests, or for the fixture or assembly.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1187#issuecomment-170439177.
Yes, I am working on the issue.  I am assuming that whatever the problem is, it affects all builds, and if fixed, it will be fixed everywhere.  Will keep you informed.
And yes, I definitely have enough of a test bed.

It appears that some real re-architecting of the abort mechanism may be required.

Since the only code in a thread which really survives a thread.abort is that which is in finally clauses, all of the bookkeeping for an aborted test needs to either be there, or outside of the thread entirely.

What seems to be happening is that only a few levels unwind before the thread just disposes itself, and there is no thread for the bookkeeping code to run on.

I am investigating both options.  Putting the bookkeeping/unwinding code outside of the thread the work item is running on may be the cleanest, but putting it into finally clauses may be easier.

issue.title: Cancelled test run may not signal completion
issue.body:
`When a test run is cancelled under NUnit using the Parallel dispatcher, it may terminate without the Completion event ever being called. Currently, our test of cancellation uses a time delay to make the test pass, but this won't be sufficient when we have a Gui and the user is able to cancel a test run.

We need to ensure that the event is signalled in all cases after the cancelled test has terminated and a result is availble.

body:
Ah! I'm on my phone and can't check this but here's what I suspect...

It unwinds successfully so long as the test is the last remaining test of the containing test. But at that point it quits. See if that helps.
Github said you closed it.  I transferred the discussion to #166.  We do not really need both, since they are the same issue.  I assumed that was why you closed it?

Not sure that is it.

I can make it fail with a single test being run, so every test is the last remaining test of the containing test.

I didn't intend to close it as you were working on it. I don't have access
to that from my phone so feel free to reopen if you like.

Github said you closed it. I transferred the discussion to #166
https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/166. We do not really need both,
since they are the same issue. I assumed that was why you closed it?

â€”
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1187#issuecomment-170502033.

"It unwinds successfully so long as the test is the last remaining test of the containing test. But at that point it quits."

That seems related to the problem.  Can you take a look at the code when you have a chance, and let me know.  It is difficult to understand what is being done there.
I have to pick up my wife who is coming home from out of town. If I get some time this evening I'll take a look then, else tomorrow.

A few... this is all based only on code reading for the moment.
1. It may behave differently in NETCF. There are a few places where calls to Thread.ResetAbort are eliminated. The logic assumes that the thread abort can be prevented after the catch ends and that a more controlled abort can take its place.
2. Try instrumenting CompositeWorkItem.CheckForCancellation to report each test checked and the result.
3. As you noted, tests don't run on the worker thread may behave differently.

I was only able to spend a little time as family activities took priority in the afternoon. It's bedtime now, but I'll try to spend more time tomorrow if you let me know what progress you make.

I am pretty sure that ResetAbort is not available on other platforms as well?

I cannot find it listed as supported for Silverlight, Portable, Core, but the documentation has been wrong before.

I think we need to find a reliable way of unwinding that does not rely on ResetAbort.
